title: Bank of England official warns rates may be cut even if no-deal Brexit averted
text:
Banking chiefs were urged to increase efforts to identify high value assets bought by traffickers: Getty Images

Sterling tumbled on Friday after a senior Bank of England official described Brexit as a “slow puncture” and warned that interest rates may have to be cut within weeks.

While the Bank itself is widely thought to be holding back on any move on rates, Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) member Michael Saunders seemed to veer from that stance.

He told a business meeting in Barnsley that interest rates might have to be cut even if the UK avoids a no-deal Brexit, because the uncertainty gripping the economy is so intense.

Saunders said: “The economy could follow very different paths depending on Brexit developments. But in my view, even assuming that the UK avoids a no-deal Brexit, persistently high Brexit uncertainties seem likely to continue to depress UK growth below potential for some time, especially if global growth remains disappointing.”

The battered pound, which had lately shown signs of recovery, tumbled more than half a cent to $1.228.

The yield on 10-year government bonds fell sharply to 0.485%. Two-year debt was down similarly.

Saunders, one of nine rate-setters on the MPC, raised fears that the UK is heading for a recession.

The economy shrank 0.2% in the second quarter. Another quarter of the same would put the UK in official recession. Until today economists had expected that to be avoided, given resilience over the summer.

The Bank has been looking to raise rates from historic lows of 0.75% and is assumed to be keen to avoid another cut. Saunders said: “In such a scenario — not a no-deal Brexit, but persistently high uncertainty — it probably will be appropriate to maintain an expansionary monetary policy stance and perhaps to loosen further.”

“The economy has not crashed,” Saunders added.

“But the effect of Brexit uncertainties is perhaps akin to the economy developing a slow puncture such that growth has slowed to a mere crawl.”

Neil Wilson at Markets.com, said: “In making the case for a cut now it conforms to the belief of many in the market that the Bank is barking up the wrong tree with its slight tightening bias in its forward guidance.”

Sebastien Clements, currency analyst at OFX, said: “Sterling had a rude awakening this morning, tumbling downwards after BoE member Saunders’ comments soured market sentiment.”
